The effect of integrating carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into a bi-functional Ni-Zeolite-Y catalyst was studied for the hydrocracking of heptane at 350 and 400 °C (total pressure of 5 bar). It was shown that the growth of CNTs on the surface of Ni-Zeolite-Y (Ni-ZY) results in enhanced stability and catalytic activity (conversion increased by 22% at 350 °C) compared to the conventional Ni-ZY. A significant increase in the initial transient kinetic rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation was also noticed. The CNT/Ni-ZY also showed reduced coke formation during the reaction as entailed by transient isothermal (400 °C) oxidation experiments. The formation of a crystalline NixCy phase on the zeolite surface was observed in the case of CNT/Ni-ZY, potentially responsible for its enhanced catalytic performance. This work demonstrates that the integration of CNTs in hydrocracking catalysts offers new opportunities for enhancing their catalytic activity, selectivity and coking resistance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Carbon nanotubes Hydroprocessing Bi-functional catalyst Surface acidity Transient kinetics 1 Introduction Heavy fuels with high boiling points are often undesirable in their existing form, and it is rather preferable to convert them into lighter, value-added chemical products through hydrocracking [1]. Hydrocracking is typically carried out in the presence of a bi-functional catalyst consisting of an acidic support, to provide the cracking function, and of dispersed metal nanoparticles, to provide both the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation functions. The catalyst composition is indeed a critical element for determining the hydrocracking performance in terms of conversion, selectivity and yield towards desired products. Catalyst supports are usually porous materials and have large surface area in order to increase the number of reaction sites on a per gram basis [2], such as amorphous silica and alumina, as well as conventional and hierarchical zeolites. In particular, zeolites are typically preferred for many hydrocracking reactions due to their relatively strong acidity, increased thermal and hydro-thermal stability, greater resistance to poisoning sulfur- and nitrogen-containing compounds, lower coke production tendency, and higher regeneration capability [3]. In addition, the porosity of zeolites induces their shape selectivity, where certain reactions are permitted, while others are suppressed, based on the size of the reactants and products. Conventional zeolites are microporous, whereas hierarchical zeolites have more than one level of porosity, typically microporosity and mesoporosity, and sometimes macroporosity [4]. Microporosity in zeolites may cause diffusion limitations of larger molecules resulting in lower mass transport rates, and thus lower reaction rates [5]. For this reason, researchers have been highly interested in synthesizing zeolites with hierarchical pore structures that would enable enhanced rates of mass transport of various molecules to the catalytically active sites [6]. Y-type zeolite is widely used for hydrocracking due to its relatively high stability and activity at high temperatures, as well as high Si/Al ratio obtained after post-synthetic treatment into an ultra-stable form [3]. Heptane, as many other hydrocarbons, can be better utilized through hydrocracking into lighter compounds. Even though there exists a number of different cracking options for paraffin molecules, such as steam cracking, and catalytic cracking, hydrocracking offers some advantages over these processes. Steam cracking, for instance, eliminates the use of a catalyst and produces valuable end products, such as ethylene and other feedstock, but yet requires a relatively high operational temperatures [7]. Steam cracking reactors also suffer from coke deposition on their walls, degrading their efficiency and requiring regular de-coking treatments. Catalytic cracking, in turn, is an alternative industrial process to hydrocracking but does not utilize hydrogen during the reaction. The produced gasoline often has an elevated octane number, however, is less chemically stable due to its olefinic profile as compared to other gasoline components [8]. On the contrary, hydrocracking operates at an elevated partial pressure of hydrogen. The hydrocracking products are saturated hydrocarbons ranging from ethane, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and up to heavier hydrocarbons depending on the reaction conditions [9]. Various studies reported on hydrocracking reactions of heptane fuel using a variety of bi-functional catalysts [10–12]. For example, graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) were doped on a Ni-based/zeolite-Y [13] to obtain a composite catalyst which was recently utilized for heptane hydrocracking reaction at different temperatures. It was reported that the integration of graphene improved the conversion by up to 31% with superior stability over 20 h time-on-stream [13]. Moreover, NiO-WO3/zeolite-Y was used for heptane hydrocracking [12], where nano-sized zeolite Y, obtained via ball milling [14,15], exhibited higher BET surface area as compared to micro-sized zeolite Y, and thus, showed superior performance in terms of conversion. Dispersed zeolite Y crystals with hierarchical pore structure on silicon carbide with the aid of a cationic template were also proposed [16], creating a hierarchical micro-mesopore assembly. The latter catalyst showed higher reaction rates and olefin yields, and lower deactivation rates in the cracking of heptane, which was attributed to the hierarchical micro- and meso-porosity, offering fast diffusion pathways and improved accessibility for reactants to active sites. NiMo/USY-Al2O3 was used for hexadecane hydrocracking [17], while TiO2/Al2O3 for propane hydrocracking [18]. The effect of ultra-stable zeolite Y (USY) recrystallization on the hydrocracking performance of bi-functional NiMo/USY-Al2O3 catalysts was reported [17], as well as the performance of various hierarchical zeolites in bi-functional hydrocracking for a wide range of feedstock [19]. Ni-based catalysts, Mo-based catalysts, and Ni,Mo (bimetallic)-based catalysts are widely utilized to catalyse both hydrocracking and hydrotreating processes [19–24], for feed molecules ranging from aromatic and paraffinic compounds to heavy petrochemicals. Hydrocracking reactions lead to carbon deposition causing reduction in catalytic activity. The coking process is first initiated when a coke precursor is formed (typically a hydrocarbon fragment) on the metallic phase of the catalyst, after which a series of reactions occur on the metal active sites (e.g., dehydrogenation). The carbon formed due to these reactions can diffuse through the metal particles, leading eventually to the formation of nanotubular or nanofibrous carbon [25]. During the progress of the reaction, additional carbon is deposited at the back end of the metal particle, facilitating the formation of extended carbon filaments, and creating what is known as filamentous coke. In some cases, carbon migration can occur on the surface of the metal, which blocks metal sites and inhibits further growth of filaments, causing a drop in the rate of dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons. Besides, coke deposition on acidic catalysts, such as zeolite Y, occurs mainly because of its strong adsorption on acidic sites, ultimately causing catalyst deactivation [25]. The coking mechanism on these sites has been associated with condensation and polymerization reactions, where carbon formation comprises hydrogen transfer reactions that occur on acidic sites, together with condensation or rearrangement of the carbonaceous compounds. Carbon filaments formed during the reaction may plug catalyst pores and pulverize catalyst pellets, leading to process shutdown. There are several ways in which catalyst decay can be prevented or minimized. Mechanical degradation could be reduced through carefully choosing carrier materials, coatings and catalyst particles forming methods [26]. Fouling by coke can be minimized by promoting the catalyst with S, Cu, or Au, for instance which reduce the speed of graphite formation on Ni by lowering ensemble size [26]. Alternatively, using metal oxide promoters lead to the decrease of carbon deposition by facilitating adsorption of water which aids to the gasification of surface carbon [26]. Ni-based catalysts are known to suffer from carbon formation upon contacting hydrocarbons such as heptane during hydrocracking [27]. For this reason, Pt and other metals are used instead of Ni as hydrocracking catalysts. However, since Pt is a relatively expensive metal, Ni is still widely used in hydrocracking catalyst developments, and thus, it becomes important to design improved Ni-based catalytic systems towards reduced coke deposition rates. The incorporation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in hydrocracking catalysts has started to attract attention because it provides a means of creating mesoporosity in the microporous zeolite framework [28]. In addition, CNTs possess several unique properties, such as excellent thermal conductivity and stability [29,30], as well as high surface area [31]. Various methodologies have been proposed for the synthesis of CNT-zeolite composites, such as the growth of zeolite on previously prepared CNTs [28,32,33], or the growth of CNTs on the surface of zeolites [34–36]. The latter approach is well known, and it is based on the catalytic decomposition of carbon-based feeds (e.g. CH4) on transition metal surfaces (e.g. Ni, Fe, Co) [37]. Under appropriate thermal conditions, methane decomposes into atomic carbon and hydrogen gas by a series of surface reactions, followed by carbon diffusion into the dispersed metal, and finally to the growth of carbon nanotubes [37]. Although several methodologies for the synthesis of CNT/zeolite composites have been reported [28,37–39], the potential benefits of using the latter composites as supports of hydrocracking catalysts remains widely unexplored. Nevertheless, there is a possibility of the reactant molecule to be converted after consecutive decompositions into filamentous carbon elongating the CNTs. In turn, this avoids the carbon formed from adsorbing onto the Ni active sites and blocking them, since the formation of whisker carbon is associated with pushing the Ni outwards, thus keeping its surface area exposed to the feed molecules. In this study, we report the integration of chemical vapor deposition (CVD)-grown CNTs into a bi-functional Ni-zeolite Y catalyst, and its performance for hydrocracking of heptane at 350 and 400 °C. The conversion and selectivity, as well as the bulk and surface properties of the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst, are compared to those of a conventional Ni-ZY catalyst (benchmark catalyst) with same Ni-loading (5 wt%). In addition, transient kinetic experiments were performed to estimate the dynamic rates and amounts of CH4 and C2H6 formed as a function of time during heptane hydrocracking, while the oxidation behavior of the coke deposits was studied by a subsequent transient isothermal oxidation, yielding kinetic rates of oxidation, total amounts of CO2 and CO formed, and the amount of carbon deposited after reaction. Furthermore, we demonstrate how the acidity of the catalyst changes during reaction conditions via in-situ monitoring the transient rates of NH3 desorption during temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) following exposure of the catalyst to the reaction feed gas stream, for the first time to the best of our knowledge. Knowing that hydrocracking of heptane is a model reaction, this work aims to unveil the role of CNTs in the reaction metrics (e.g., conversion and selectivity) and provide fundamental understanding of coke formation and acidity changes of hydrocracking catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Zeolite Y was purchased from Zeolyst International (code: CBV720, SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 30), here referred to as ZY for convenience. 2.1.1 Ni-ZY catalyst synthesis Zeolite Y support was first impregnated using nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) as precursor by the wet impregnation method. The amounts of Ni precursor and zeolite were chosen to achieve 5 wt% Ni deposition on the zeolite. After wet impregnation, the catalyst was dried for 12 h at 120 °C and then cooled at room temperature. Half of the obtained catalyst quantity was then used for CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst preparation, while the other half was further processed for Ni-ZY preparation as follows: First, Ni-ZY was calcined in air at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain NiO-ZY, and then reduced in situ in H2 at 550 °C to obtain Ni nanoparticles on the zeolite prior to catalytic testing. 2.1.2 CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst synthesis The NiO-ZY (as synthesized, without calcination) was placed in the Microactivity apparatus (PID-Micromeritics) in an Inconel fixed-bed reactor (internal diameter of 9 mm). The catalyst sample (ca. 0.5 g) was calcined in 20% O2/He at 500 °C for 1 h and reduced in H2 at 500 °C for 45 min, followed by in situ CNT growth through methane decomposition (100% CH4 flow (1 bar) at 500 °C for 2 h). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The as-prepared (fresh) catalysts, as well as the spent catalysts (after 3 h time-on-stream) were characterized using various analytical techniques for an in-depth investigation of their bulk and surface properties, which are briefly described in what follows. 2.2.1 Textural properties The specific surface area and porosity of the fresh catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77 K using a 3Flex physisorption porosimeter (Micrometrics, Atlanta, USA). The surface area and micropore volume were estimated by applying the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method and t-plots, respectively. The pore size distribution of the catalysts was obtained using the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method. Before carrying out the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements, the catalysts were degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 5 h to remove previously adsorbed gases in their pore system. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction The crystalline structure of the fresh catalysts was examined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, using the Bruker D2 Phaser XRD apparatus (λ = 1.54184 Å (Cu-Kα), operated at 30 kV and 10 mA, 2θ between 5° and 80°). 2.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The elemental oxidation states and chemical environment of the near surface atoms in the solid catalysts were investigated using X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). XPS analysis was carried out on a Thermo-Fisher Scientific Instruments (East Grinstead, UK) K-Alpha+ spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). An X-ray spot of 400 µm and a pass energy of 50 eV were used for recording high-resolution core level spectra. All spectra were charge referenced against the C 1s peak at 285.0 eV. Elemental quantification was performed using the high-resolution core level spectra, following the removal of a non-linear (Shirley) background. The Thermo-Fisher Scientific Advantage software used incorporated the appropriate sensitivity factors and corrected for the electron energy analyzer transmission function. 2.2.4 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopic measurements were conducted on a Raman-AFM combination (Witec Alpha 300 RA) for the fresh catalyst samples. The characteristics of the grown carbon nanotubes (CNTs) was examined using a laser wavelength of 532 nm. 2.2.5 Scanning/Transmission Electron Microscopy imaging (SEM/TEM) The morphologies of the secondary particles (agglomerates) of fresh catalysts were observed using High Resolution Scanning Electron Microscopy (HR-SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). HR-SEM imaging on the reduced catalysts, Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY, was performed after using an FEI Nova NanoSEM 650, while TEM imaging after using an FEI Tecnai instrument with a line resolution of 0.20 nm. 2.2.6 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (TPD-NH3) technique was used to characterize the surface acidity of NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY solids. The fresh catalyst sample (ca. 0.03 g) was reduced at 400 °C, to avoid thermal decomposition of the CNTs at higher temperatures and thus maintain the integrity of the catalyst, for 1 h in pure H2 (1 bar) and then cooled in He gas flow to 25 °C. The feed gas was then switched to 1000 ppm NH3/He gas mixture for 30 min. Following this adsorption step, a switch to He gas-flow was made and kept at 25 °C until practically no ammonia desorption was measured (ca. 35 min). The temperature of the solid was then increased from 25 to 600 °C in He gas flow (50 N mL min−1) at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The NH3 (m/z = 15), N2 (m/z = 28), NO (m/z = 30) and N2O (m/z = 44) signals were continuously monitored by an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (Balzers, Omnistar 1–200 amu). To investigate how carbon accumulation under reaction conditions affects the surface acidity of the solids, a similar NH3-TPD procedure after reaction was followed. The fresh catalyst sample (ca. 0.1 g) was reduced at 400 °C for 1 h in pure H2 (1 bar), and the reactor was then purged in He gas flow for 10 min. The feed was then switched to 25% C7H16/75% H2 at 400 °C followed by He purge for 30 min. The reactor was then cooled in He flow to 25 °C. Ammonia adsorption followed by TPD-NH3 were applied, as previously described, after 1, 2 and 3 h time-on-stream in 25% C7H16/75% H2 at 400 °C. 2.2.7 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (TPD-H2) was performed in a chemisorption AutoChem II 2920 unit (Micrometrics) for the fresh catalysts to evaluate the metal (Ni) dispersion. The steps involved in TPD-H2 were as follows: He gas flow was passed while ramping the temperature to 400 °C at a rate of 30 °C/min, and which was kept at this temperature for 60 min. The temperature of the solid was then reduced to 30 °C at a rate of 30 °C /min in He gas flow, followed by 10% H2/Ar treatment for 60 min (adsorption). He gas was then allowed to flow until the baseline signal stabilized. Recording was subsequently started while ramping the temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C /min (desorption step). Finally, the sample was cooled to room temperature. The metal dispersion and particle size were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively [40,41]: (1) D m ( % ) = V Chem / 22 , 414 x SF x MW ( m x p ) / 100 x 100 (2) S m = 6 ( A m ( metal ) x ρ x 10 6 ) x 10 9 where D m is the metal dispersion (%), V Chem is the adsorption amount (cm3), m is the sample mass (g), p is the weight percent of metal content in the catalyst (wt%), MW is the molar weight of metal (g/mol), SF is the stoichiometry factor of adsorption (metal atom per H2 molecule), S m is the size of metal particle (nm), A m is the area per gram (nm2/g) of active metal, and ρ is the density of active metal (g/nm3) [42]. 2.2.8 H2 Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) The degree of Ni reducibility in the supported Ni catalysts was assessed employing H2 Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) using the AutoChem II 2920 unit over the fresh catalysts. The steps involved in H2-TPR were the following: He gas was passed over the catalyst while ramping the temperature to 400 °C at a rate of 30 °C/min; the temperature was then reduced to 30 °C at a rate of 30 °C/min; the gas flow was then switched to 10% H2/Ar while recording and at the same time raising the temperature to 600 °C started; He gas was finally allowed to flow during cooling from 600 °C to room temperature at a rate of 30 °C/min. 2.2.9 Transient kinetic rates and coking studies for the n-C7H16/H2 reaction Prior to any transient kinetic measurements, the fresh catalyst sample was reduced in pure H2 (1 bar) at 400 °C for 1 h (30 N mL min−1). The reaction feed consisted of 25 vol% C7H16 and 75 vol%H2, the total volume flow rate (FT) was 30 N mL min−1, and the catalytic bed (Wcat = 0.1 g) consisted of the catalyst in powder form (< 0.2 mm in size). The reaction feed gas stream composition (yi, mol%) from the outlet of the quartz micro-reactor (CSTR performance) [43] was monitored by online mass spectrometer for CH4 (m/z = 15) and C2H6 (m/z = 30). The transient rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation (mols gcat −1 s−1) after the step-gas concentration switch He → 25%C7H16/75%H2(400 °C, t) at ∼ 1 bar total pressure, were estimated using the following Eqs. (3) and (4), which are based on the material balance applied for CH4 and C2H6, respectively. The accumulation term ((NT/Wcat) dyi/dt) in the material balance was found very small, thus it was neglected; NT is the total number of mols in the reactor, and yi is the mole fraction of component i (CH4 or C2H6) in the CSTR micro-reactor. It was also found that the heptane conversion during the whole transient period was less than 10%. Thus, the transient rates given by Eqs. (3)–(4) are considered as true kinetic rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation for the applied feed gas composition. (3) R CH 4 t = F T W cat y CH 4 (4) R C 2 H 6 t = F T W cat y C 2 H 6 ( t ) The activity and amount (mg C gcat −1) of carbon accumulated after 1, 2 and 3 h of reaction time in 25% C7H16/75% H2 at 400 °C towards oxygen were characterized as follows. After the fresh catalyst (ca. 0.1 g) was reduced at 400 °C for 1 h in pure hydrogen and exposed to the 25% C7H16/75% H2 feed gas stream for 1 h at 400 °C, the reactor was then purged in He gas flow for 30 min, and the feed was subsequently switched to 2 vol% O2/He (50 N ml min−1) for 30 min to perform a transient isothermal oxidation (TIO) of carbon, the latter being formed during the hydrocracking reaction. At the end of the TIO experiment, the catalyst was reduced (pure H2/1 h) at 400 °C, purged in He for 30 min, and the feed was then switched to the C7H16/H2 feed gas stream to start the next run for 2 h on reaction stream. At the end of this run, the catalyst was pretreated in He and H2 at the same conditions as of the previous run (1 h reaction), and the feed was then switched back to the C7H16/H2 feed gas stream for the next run of reaction (3 h). The mass numbers (m/z) 28 and 44 were used for CO and CO2, respectively. Quantification of CO and CO2 signals was made using standard calibration gas mixtures, ca. 2 vol% CO/He and 10 vol% CO2/He, respectively. The different kinds of carbonaceous species and the total amount (mg C g−1) of carbon accumulated after 3 h in 25%C7H16/75%H2 over the NiO-ZY catalyst was also investigated via temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO). After reaction (3 h), the feed was switched to He for 30 min, where CO2, CO, H2, CH4 and C2H6 signals in the mass spectrometer reached their background values. The catalyst sample was then cooled in He gas-flow to 50 °C and the feed was switched to 10% O2/He (50 NmL min−1), while at the same time the temperature of the catalyst was increased to 600 °C at the rate of β = 10 °C min−1. The CO (m/z = 28) and CO2 (m/z = 44) were continuously monitored by online MS and converted into concentration (mol%) using certified calibration gas mixtures (2% CO/He and 10% CO2/He). 2.3 Catalytic testing Heptane hydrocracking experiments were carried out in an Autoclave Engineers BTRS high- temperature and high-pressure testing system, equipped with a high-pressure HPLC pump (Series I) and metering valves to control the flow rate of liquid and gas feed, respectively. 2.3.1 Procedure A continuous flow, fixed-bed tubular stainless-steel reactor with an internal diameter of 0.7 cm and 30 cm in length (volume of 12 mL) was used in the catalytic experiments. For the Ni-ZY catalyst, reduction in pure H2 (50 mL/min) in atmospheric pressure was carried out in situ prior to catalytic testing, whereas CNT/Ni-ZY was reduced during the catalyst preparation process. The system was set to the desired reaction temperature under a flow of high purity N2 gas (100 mL/min), and then pressurized with H2 gas at 5 bar. Heptane (> 99% purity) in liquid state was introduced in the system at the rate of 0.035 mL/min along with a flow of pure H2 gas. Liquid and gaseous reaction products were passed through a liquid-gas separator, placed downstream from the reactor, where liquid products were manually collected for the analysis (GC/MS system), while the gas stream was directed to the GC. The heptane hydrocracking catalytic experiments were conducted at two different reaction temperatures, ca. 350 and 400 °C, a H2 pressure of 5 bar, a Liquid Hourly Space Velocity (LHSV) of 4.2 h−1, and a H2/heptane ratio of 3:1. Each test was performed for 3 h using a fresh catalyst, and the liquid products were analyzed every 1 h interval. Also, stability tests were carried after 20 h time-on-stream for each catalyst. 2.3.2 Product analysis The liquid samples were analyzed on an Agilent 7890A/5975C Triple-Axis Detector diffusion pump Gas Chromatography - Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS), equipped with an Agilent Multimode inlet. High injection and appropriate column temperatures were used to directly analyze n-alkanes to avoid chemical derivatization. The split/splitless injector was operated in split mode with a split ratio of 25:1 and a split flow of 50 mL/min using deactivated open ended helix liner (Agilent Technologies). The temperature of the inlet was set at 300 °C for the duration of the analysis, and the volume of each sample injected was 1 μL. The oven temperature was initially set at 30 °C for 8 min, and then it was increased by a rate of 8 °C/min to 250 °C. The maximum temperature was maintained for 5 min and the total run lasted for 40 min. An Agilent 30 m × 320 μm × 0.1 μm J&W DB5-HT capillary column (5% phenyl, 95% methylpolysiloxane) was employed to achieve chromatographic separation, operated under a constant flow rate mode (He gas, 2 mL/min). The temperature of the ion source, the quadrupole, and the MS interface for both instruments were kept at 230, 150 and 330 °C, respectively. The GC/MSD Chemstation software was used to record chromatographic data. The gaseous reaction products were analyzed online by gas chromatography (GC-Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph) with two columns in parallel, HP Plot-Q (19095-Q04, 30 m length, 0.530 mm i.d.), and HP-Molsieve (19095P-MSO, 30 m length, 0.530 mm i.d.) equipped with TCD and FID detectors. 2.3.3 Reaction metrics The conversion (%) of heptane was estimated using Eq. (5): (5) % conversion = ( X i − X f X i ) * 100 where X i is the inlet to the reactor heptane molar flow rate (mols/min), and X f is the outlet heptane molar flow rate (mols/min) from the reactor. The selectivity, Si (%) of each product, i, was estimated according to Eq. (6): (6) S i ( % ) = ( C atoms in species i total C atoms found in the products ) * 100 where species i refers to ethylene, ethane, methane, propane, iso-butane, n-butane and n-hexane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts textural characterization Table 1 presents the BET surface areas, micropore and total pore volumes, as well as the average pore diameters obtained from N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K of the NiO-ZY, CNT/Ni-ZY and ZY solid catalysts. After impregnation of ZY with Ni and calcination, the BET surface area decreased from 560 to 536 m2 g−1 attributed to a slight pore blockage as Ni particles deposit on the micropores of the zeolite. This effect can also be noticed but to a smaller extent looking at the micropore volume decrease, ca. from 0.23 to 0.2 cm3 g−1, with a simultaneous increase in the average pore diameter, attributed to the widening of the pores upon calcination. In contrast, the CNT/Ni-ZY solid had a significantly higher surface area, ca. 612 m2 g−1 compared to ZY (560 m2 g−1) and NiO-ZY (536 m2 g−1). Additionally, the formation of CNTs contributed to a slight increase in micropore volume, from 0.20 to 0.22 cm3 g−1, and a more pronounced increase in mesopore volume, from 0.18 to 0.22 cm3 g−1. Note that the experimental error is ∼ 0.075 cm3 g−1 for the specific volume, and ∼ 0.3 m2 g−1 for the specific surface area [44]. The micropore volume was determined by applying the t-plot statistical thickness method, which involves measuring the thickness of the N2 adsorbate layer as a function of relative pressure, p/p 0. The statistical thickness can then be calculated using the de Boer Eq. (7) [45]: (7) t A = 13.99 0.034 − log ⁡ ( P / P o ) 1 / 2 The average pore diameter is given by the ratio 4V T/S BET, where V T is the specific total volume and S BET is the specific surface area [46]. Fig. 1 presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, BJH pore size distribution, and Horváth‐Kawazoe (HK) pore‐size distribution, for the ZY, NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY solids. The isotherms are of type-IV, according to the IUPAC classification, depicting mesoporous materials, while the hysteresis loop is of H3-type, due to the presence of slit-shaped pores. The force on the hysteresis loop, shown by the sharp slope during desorption at the relative pressure of ∼ 0.45, is associated with the tensile strength effect occurring for N2 at 77 K at this relative pressure range [47]. Although the type of isotherm was similar among the three catalytic materials, higher N2 adsorption level was noticed over the CNT/Ni-ZY compared to NiO-ZY and ZY, which is consistent with their respective specific surface areas and pore structures as explained earlier. 3.2 Catalysts structure and morphology characterization Fig. 2a presents the powder X-ray diffractograms in the 5– 80° 2θ range of ZY, NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY solids. The sharp peaks in the XRD patterns show that the crystallinities of both NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY solids are maintained after the CNT growth process. A zoom-in to the region of 35–80° is shown in Fig. 2b, where the diffraction peaks corresponding to Ni and NiO are clearly highlighted, as well as those associated with a NixCy phase that was formed during the CNT growth process. The presence of NiO is characterized by three major diffraction peaks associated with the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of the cubic structure, whereas Ni diffraction peaks associated with the (111), (200) and (220) planes at different 2θ values are shown in Fig. 2b. Depending on the stoichiometry y/x, a number of different diffraction patterns can exist for NixCy, whose peaks are indexed for the (111), (200) and (311) planes of the NiC phase (y = x = 1) [48]. CNTs are indexed by two major peaks at 26.0 and 43.4° 2theta, corresponding to the (002) and (100) planes [49], respectively. Since the CNT peaks occur at very similar 2θ values to those associated with zeolite and Ni, Raman spectroscopy and TEM imaging were used to confirm the formation of the CNT structures as presented below. Fig. 2b clearly shows the presence of NiO in NiO-ZY catalyst (XRD was performed before reduction in H2), and confirms the successful reduction of NiO to Ni in the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst before the growth of CNTs. NiC crystal phase diffraction peaks are visible in the CNT/Ni-ZY solid, particularly the (111) and (200) planes, which are shown clearly in Fig. 2c and d, respectively. However, these are very close to the (100) plane of CNT and the (200) plane of Ni. Thus, the presence of NiC phase was further confirmed by XPS analysis (Section 3.3). It can also be seen that the major diffraction angles of the ZY framework, 9.9, 11.7, 15.3, 20.2, and 23.6°, are shifted to higher values in NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY, namely: 10.3, 12.1, 15.9, 20.6, and 24.1°, respectively, associated with the Ni incorporation into the zeolite lattice structure following the impregnation procedure. Fig. 3a shows the Raman spectra obtained for ZY, NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts. While the ZY and NiO-ZY show a similar band structure, the Raman spectra for the CNT/Ni-ZY composite shows three additional bands representing the G-band, D-band, and G′ band at ∼ 1577, 1345 and 2689 cm−1, respectively, confirming the formation of nanotube structure for the deposited carbon. The G-band is associated with the presence of crystalline graphitic carbon composed of sp2 bonded carbon, while the D-band originating from a hybridized vibrational mode, is an indication of defective carbon and lattice distortions depicting the weaker sp3 bonds. The ID/IG ratio (i.e. relative intensities of D and G bands) is ∼ 1.3, which is consistent with reported values (0.5–1.3) for CVD-grown CNTs [50]. The defects in the synthesized CNTs play a role in enhancing the binding strength of surface metal atoms (here of Ni) and catalytic activity of metal-supported materials, arising from the strong interaction between the metal nanoparticles and the defective CNT surface [51,52]. The remaining bands located at 115, 303 and 502 cm−1 are attributed to the zeolite framework in ZY, and these are shifted to 125, 309 and 500 cm−1 for the NiO-ZY, and to 130, 309 and 500 cm−1 for the CNT/Ni-ZY solid (Fig. 3b). The shift towards higher wavenumbers result from the incorporation of Ni into the zeolite structure upon impregnation, and originate from induced local lattice strain which causes changes in local bond strengths [53], in agreement with the present XRD results. Additionally, the growth of CNTs leads to a further shift in a single Raman band from 125 to 130 cm−1, while the other bands maintained their positions relative to those of NiO-ZY. Fig. 4 shows HR-SEM and TEM images of reduced NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts. Ni particles on the zeolite surface are visible in HR-SEM (see Fig. 4a), while TEM image of reduced NiO/ZY (Fig. 4b) shows evidence of successful impregnation of few nanometer-sized Ni particles on the zeolite. Fig. 4c and d present HR-SEM and TEM images of CNTs with diameter of ∼ 50 nm, respectively, showing that the growth of CNTs can be well described by the “tip-growth model”. This growth model is favored when the metal-substrate interaction is weak, and results in metal forming an acute angle with the substrate [54]. Methane decomposes through successive dehydrogenation steps (CH4→ CH3→ CH2→ CH→ C) on the metal surface, after which the carbon diffuses across the boundaries of metal (Ni) crystallites, precipitates on the bottom of the metal, and finally pushes the metal particle upwards. During the CNT growth, NixC phase has been also formed as the carbon interacts with the Ni particles, as indicated by the powder XRD (Fig. 2) and XPS ( Fig. 5) results. At a later stage, during hydrocracking, Ni particles are gradually released out of the NixC phase through its decomposition towards fcc-Ni and C, ensuring that a major part of Ni was protected by being encapsulated in NixC. 3.3 Catalysts surface elemental composition and chemical states – XPS analysis To provide information on the surface chemical environment and elemental composition, XPS was carried out for the calcined and reduced catalysts. XPS Ni 2p narrow scans for Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY, together with a C 1s narrow scan peak fit for CNT/Ni-ZY are shown in Fig. 5. The Ni 2p3/2 peak occurs at a binding energy between 855 and 856 eV for both the Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts (Fig. 5a). There are different nickel oxide/hydroxide species which exhibit similar binding energies and complex peak shapes [55–57]. The peak position and shape for both the Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts would suggest the presence of predominantly Ni2+ oxides/hydroxides at the surface; a hydroxide layer typically forms on the surface of the metal oxides as a result of ambient air exposure. A low binding energy shoulder (∼ 853.0 eV) can be clearly observed for CNT/Ni-ZY, which is less evident but still present for Ni-ZY. During the CNT growth, hydrogen produced during methane decomposition is expected to further reduce the NiO phase, transforming Ni2+ species into Ni0, resulting in a more pronounced Ni0 peak. Furthermore, as will be seen in both the C 1s spectra and the XRD results, nickel carbide is also formed as a result of CNT growth, and Ni3C is expected at a binding energy of 853.5 eV [58]. Hence, the higher intensity low-binding energy Ni 2p shoulder for the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst results from the presence of both Ni metal and Ni carbide phases. The carbon concentrations and C 1s binding energies are representative of the different compositions of the CNT/Ni-ZY and Ni-ZY catalysts. There is a carbon concentration of 5.8 at% for CNT/Ni-ZY, compared to 2.4–2.7 at% for Ni-ZY and ZY catalysts due to the incorporation of CNTs into the structure. The C 1s peak for CNT/Ni-ZY is shown in Fig. 5b. The components of interest are the strong peak at 284.5 eV and the smaller peak at lower binding energy, ca. 283.6 eV. The former corresponds to the CNTs [59] and the latter to Ni carbide [58]. Other peaks at higher binding energies correspond to oxidized carbon species. For the three materials, the Si 2p, Al 2p and O 1s peaks are found at binding energies of 103.6 ± 0.1 eV, 74.8 ± 0.1 eV and 532.9 ± 0.1 eV, in good agreement with those for sodalite, (Al0.2Si0.8)O2.2, an aluminosilicate of a similar composition [60]. The Si/Al ratio of the different catalysts is 22.5, 20.6, and 25.4 for ZY, Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY, respectively. The sites where Al is present in the zeolite increase the surface acidity, and it is these sites of higher acidity where coking/CNT formation occurs. In particular, these acid sites are the second source of acidity, Lewis acidity, and are attributed to both framework and extra-framework aluminum species (EFAL), while Brønsted acid sites arise from the bridging hydroxyl groups between Al and Si tetrahedral [61]. Hence, the increase in the Si/Al ratio for the CNT-containing sample is probably due to the surface Al species being preferentially buried beneath the CNT/coke, causing the concentration of Al in the XPS spectra to drop, as observed. Therefore, this increase in the Si/Al ratio is indirect evidence of CNTs preferentially formed at the more acidic Al-rich sites on the zeolite surface. Carbon deposition mainly occurs at the strong Brönsted acid sites in the zeolite framework, particularly over the strong acid site density (Si–OH–Al) species over the catalyst, as widely reported in literature, which explains the preferential growth of CNTs on the Al-rich species and thus the increase in the surface Si/Al ratio of the corresponding catalyst as indicated by XPS analysis [62–64]. Also, the increase in Si/Al ratio of the surface indicates a decrease in surface acidity with a simultaneous increase in the strength of the acid sites of CNT/Ni-ZY surface [65], as will be shown in Section 3.4. 3.4 Monitoring catalyst surface acidity under heptane hydrocracking reaction conditions Fig. 6 shows desorption rates of NH3 (a) and N2 formation rates (b) obtained during TPD in He gas flow for the fresh and reduced NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts. In general, the desorption peaks in the low-temperature range of 100–300 °C correspond to weak acid sites, and in the higher temperature range of 300–600 °C to medium/strong acid sites [66,67]. The NH3 desorption curves show four major peaks for both catalysts, named T1, T2, T3 and T4 (from lower to higher temperature, Fig. 6a), and a shoulder in the falling part of T4, with peak maximum temperatures at 70, 130, 205 and 260 °C, respectively (Fig. 6a). While T1 peak is associated with very weakly chemisorbed NH3, the T2 peak is attributed to weak adsorption of NH3 molecules over the surface terminal silanol (Si–OH) groups, whereas the high-T shoulder of T4 peak is attributed to surface Brønsted acid sites originating from bridged hydroxyl groups (Si–OH–Al) present in ZY [68]. The T2 peak is in accordance with the TPD-NH3 studies for protonated Ni-ZY [69]. T3 and T4 peaks rather represent Lewis acid sites that are linked with the extra-framework Al species, which possess weaker strength than the bridged hydroxyls in ZY [68]. Thus, it can be concluded that a higher concentration of surface terminal silanol groups exist in the reduced NiO-ZY compared to CNT/Ni-ZY, while the latter has more Lewis acid sites per gram basis, but the amounts (per gram basis) of Brønsted acid sites are similar for both catalysts. As for the N2 production traces (Fig. 6b), it is evident that two significantly larger desorption peaks are formed at lower temperatures for CNT/Ni-ZY as compared to the reduced NiO-ZY, and one N2 peak of similar size at higher temperatures. The formation of N2(g) is due to the oxidation of two strongly adsorbed ammonia species on adjacent acidic sites leading in addition to the production of water (not presented). The N2 formation traces appear at T > 250 °C, where ammonia desorption rate is significantly smaller than that at lower temperatures (Fig. 6a). The oxygen source in both catalytic systems is expected to originate from the lattice oxygen of the zeolite framework, as well as from any NiO phase that was not completely reduced in H2 before NH3 chemisorption, although studies reported in the literature do not accurately identify the nature of oxygen species responsible for the NH3 oxidation [70]. Zeolite-based catalysts are frequently used for NH3 selective catalytic oxidation into N2. NH3 molecules can be adsorbed on both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites, which, upon heating, will be activated by abstraction of hydrogen atoms to form -NH2, -NH or -N intermediates. Depending on the availability of oxygen, the latter can be converted to N2, NOx and N2O. Moreover, the high Brönsted acidity strength in zeolites facilitates ammonia adsorption as NH4 + which serves as an additional reservoir of chemisorbed NH3, particularly in the high-temperature range. Note that this oxidation reaction is highly dependent on the catalyst support and metal loading [71]. For example, NH3 oxidation activity per metal site was found to be larger for a silica than alumina support [71]. Additionally, zeolite Y modified with various transition metals by ion-exchange was reported to be active in the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO process) [72]. The order of decreasing activity of transition metal modified zeolites was found to be: CuY > CrY > AgY > CoY > FeY > NiY ~ MnY [72]. Fig. 6c and d shows NH3-TPD profiles obtained over the reduced NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts, respectively, before reaction (t = 0 h) and after heptane hydrocracking (25 vol% C7H16/75 vol% H2) reaction at 400 °C for 1, 2 and 3 h time-on-stream (TOS). The presented desorption rates indicate that the number of acid sites (particularly the weak acid sites) was reduced after hydrocracking for both catalysts, and this becomes more pronounced with increasing TOS. The latter is due to the fact that the acid sites of the catalyst were blocked by coke deposits accumulated during reaction. The high-T shoulder of T4 (Fig. 6a) now appears as visible peak at ∼ 330 °C. It has been reported also that upon coke formation, the strength of the acidic sites in zeolites is affected more significantly than their population [73], in agreement with the present NH3-TPD traces (Fig. 6c and d). A consistent shift in the NH3 desorption peaks towards higher temperatures is evident for the spent catalysts (t = 1, 2 and 3 h TOS) compared to their corresponding fresh catalyst (t = 0 h), suggesting that stronger adsorption of NH3 occurs over the surface terminal silanol (Si–OH) groups in the spent catalysts, while depletion of weak acid sites can also be noticed. To better explain the surface acidity results, the surface acid sites were quantified, and their amounts (mmol g−1) are reported in Table 2 for the reduced NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts after calcination and heptane/H2 reaction for 0, 1, 2 and 3 h TOS. It is seen that the acidity dropped by ∼ 26% after 3 h of hydrocracking for the reduced NiO-ZY, and by ∼ 32% for the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst. This result shows that the former catalyst was slightly more resistant to a decrease in the surface concentration of acid sites as compared to CNT/Ni-ZY. As previously deduced from Fig. 6b, the amount of N2 produced during TPD (Table 2) was significantly higher for the fresh CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst and after 1 h of reaction time, but it remained practically the same compared to NiO-ZY after 3 h TOS. This might suggest the formation of new adjacent active sites for NH3 adsorption and reaction to N2 and water, where CNTs might play a role. 3.5 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 The dispersion (D, %) of Ni in the catalysts and the corresponding Ni particle size (d, nm) were estimated based on the TPD-H2 study using Eqs. (1) and (2), and results are summarized in Table 3. The estimated values show that Ni particles were poorly dispersed in both catalysts, but were more dispersed and smaller in the case of Ni-ZY (~ 4.1% and 24 nm) compared to CNT/Ni-ZY (~ 3.0% and 33 nm). These results might be linked to the fact that the larger mean pore diameter in the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst (see Table 1) fascilitates the formation of larger metal particles, resulting in lower metal dispersion [42]. In general, Ni-zeolite catalyst combination tends to form relatively poorly dispersed and large Ni0 particles (20–30 nm) [74–76], in accordance with the present results (Table 3). As a result of this, several approaches were considered to improve their particle size and dispersion through the tuning of preparation conditions [75]. For example, adjusting the calcination and pre-reduction temperatures, as well as the incorporation of promoters could be key parameters for ensuring the presence of well dispersed zeolites supported metal catalysts [75]. The distribution of Ni2+ sites in the ZY after impregnation (before calcination or reduction) is driven by the distribution of the negative charge in the zeolite framework, as the result of the given Si4+/Al3+ ratio of 15 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 30), for charge compensation. After reduction in H2, Ni0 particles were formed in both catalysts as concluded from the TPD-H2 measurements. This shows that the presence of CNTs impacts the Ni distribution in the catalyst, which affects the acid properties of the catalyst since Ni or Ni2+ compensates framework charge, as shown in Section 3.4. The two catalytic systems, Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY were obtained under different pretreatments, producing different mean Ni particle size, thus the concentration of surface acid sites in the intra-zeolitic space and in the mesopores/micropores will be affected. This can be supported by the findings listed in Table 2, where the amount of NH3 desorbed was higher for Ni-ZY compared to CNT/Ni-ZY. As for the TPD-H2 profiles shown in Fig. 7a, both catalysts portray two broad overlapping desorption peaks in the 100–400 °C range, although the peaks corresponding to Ni-ZY are slightly shifted to higher temperatures. While the first peak in both catalysts is associated with H2 chemisorbed on the Ni surface, the second peak is related to H2 accommodated between the Ni and the zeolite support (interfacial hydrogen) [77]. Notice that an additional major desorption peak also exists at ~ 556 °C mainly for the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst. The latter peak results from H2 species on the support away from the Ni particles, which was excluded from the Ni dispersion and particle size estimations. This peak can also be attributed to H2 spillover and/or reoxidation of Ni by water inherent on the catalyst after reduction [78]. Studies have shown that TPD reproducing runs for the same material sample resulted in decreasing area under the TPD trace in the second run, but the area (amount of chemisorption) stays constant in the subsequent runs [78,79]. The effect of slightly higher intensity in the first run might be due to H2 storage in the support during reduction followed by reverse spillover to the Ni phase and desorption during TPD [78]. It is to be noted that the use of H2-TPD on supported Ni catalysts is prone to H2 spillover, and pre-treatment conditions and the mode of H2 adsorption (partial pressure and T) preceding TPD have a major impact on the desorption signal. A careful design of the TPD experiment is thus necessary. 3.6 H2 Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The profiles of H2-TPR are shown in Fig. 7b. The size of NiO and its interaction with the support both determine the extent of its reducibility, which is important for understanding the influence of redox properties of the catalyst on its performance. Reduction peaks at low temperatures arise from weak NiO-support interactions, while relatively high temperature peaks are due to strong interactions [80]. The H2-TPR profiles of NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY show several H2 consumption peaks over the 100–600 °C range for both catalysts. It can be noticed that CNT/Ni-ZY exhibits high-temperature peaks (TM ~ 422 and 545 °C) compared to the lower temperature peaks (TM ~ 334, 395 and 535 °C) of NiO-ZY, indicating stronger NiO-support interactions for the former catalyst. The presence of several peaks can be attributed to the reduction of different Ni species in terms of size and degree of interaction (loose/strong) with the support. In particular, the reduction peaks in the 250–500 °C range relate to the reduction of Ni2+ (NiO) to metallic Ni0 [81]. Since a couple of peaks exist in this range for NiO-ZY, the first major peak at ~ 334 °C is assigned to the Ni3+ reduction into Ni2+, while the second peak at ~ 395 oC is ascribed to the Ni2+ reduction into Ni0 [82]. In the model H2-TPR trace of bulk NiO, a single reduction peak often exists at ∼ 400 °C, whereas the H2-TPR of supported NiO produces a number of peaks which might broaden the whole reduction profile and shift it to higher temperatures, as in the case of the present zeolite-supported Ni catalysts [83]. Peaks existing at lower temperatures are assigned to reduction of Ni3+ /Ni2+ oxides, while the peak ∼ 400 °C is due to the presence of large crystallites of bulk nickel oxide [83]. Higher temperature peaks, such as those appeared ∼ 500 °C and above, result from Ni2+ more difficult to be reduced. The latter are either attributed to surface nickel silicates or to difficultly reducible NiO particles [83]. In the H2-TPR profiles of the two present catalysts, CNT/Ni-ZY shows major peaks in the high-temperature range, and only a minor peak at ∼ 400 °C, which is also likely attributed to the preparation conditions applied for this catalyst. This is likely the case since NiO reduction by hydrogen was conducted in-situ prior to the growth of the CNTs, as explained earlier, which reduces the availability of Ni2+ species. Therefore, it is logical to suggest that mostly nickel silicates and hardly reducible NiO particles contribute to the H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 7b). 3.7 Catalytic performance studies Fig. 8a shows the heptane conversion (%) for the reduced NiO-ZY (Ni-ZY) and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts at 350 and 400 °C. The CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst exhibits higher conversions than the conventional Ni-ZY, ~ 76% compared to 62% at 350 °C, and 84% compared to 78% at 400 °C after 3 h time-on-stream. This activity performance presents ~ 22% improvement in conversion at 350 °C and ~ 7% at 400 °C. The reproducibility of the experimental results for the Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts was tested by carrying out a number of repeated experiments (at least three times). From these experiments, 95% confidence intervals for the mean value were calculated, and the individual experimental values are well within the corresponding confidence intervals. Fig. 8b and c show selectivity (%) results of various reaction products (mainly isomerization and cracking products) at 350 and 400 °C for the Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts, respectively. The different pore structure of the two catalysts is reasonably expected to lead to different product distributions, and for some of the products, the temperature dependence of selectivity was much higher (e.g. n-hexane) [84]. One of the main observations is that CNT/Ni-ZY is significantly more selective towards propane than Ni-ZY (SC3H8 = 45% compared to 27% at 350 °C, and 44% compared to 25% at 400 °C), reporting an increase of 70% and 75% at 350 and 400 °C, respectively. The CNT/Ni-ZY exhibits significantly lower selectivity values towards heavier hydrocarbons (e.g., n-hexane and iso-butane) than Ni-ZY. Regarding the effect of temperature, only minor differences are observed in product selectivity (%) values, apart from an increase in selectivity towards n-hexane. The enhanced catalytic performance of CNT/Ni-ZY and in particular of products selectivity can be explained based not only on its higher BET surface area, but also on the lower rate of coke formation, to be discussed in Section 3.8, and the presence of NixCy phase that protects Ni particles against sintering, as mentioned earlier. It is well known that zeolite-based catalysts enable tuning of the product distribution by restricting the pore access of reacting species, or the transition state formation of particular reactions in the reaction network, owing to their shape-selective effects [85]. Specifically, medium-pore zeolites are typically applied in light and middle distillate hydrocracking to suppress undesired β-scission towards less valuable light gases; shape selectivity could shift the hydrocracking product slate more towards the cracking or the isomerization side depending on the pore size and connectivity. Moreover, the activity and product selectivity of a bifunctional hydrocracking catalyst strongly depend on the balance between the acid and the metal function [85]. During the short lifetime of olefinic intermediates, several acid sites can be encountered during the transport between two metal sites and, consequently, could result in more than a single isomerization or cracking reaction step in between consecutive (de)hydrogenation steps. The latter phenomenon is often referred to as secondary cracking, and gives rise to a higher cracking selectivity than would normally be expected. As a result, multi-branched isomers and cracking products appear as primary products, while they are still formed from mono-branched isomer intermediates which may chemisorb on a second acid site rather than hydrogenate to an alkane. The dimerization and secondary cracking rates are also affected by the catalyst acidity, while the acid site density determines the frequency and the ease at which the olefinic intermediates are protonated to a reactive carbenium ion. It should also be noted that reactants undergo consecutive reactions, the mechanism of which highly depends on the balance between metal and acid functions, in which very strong acid sites lead to several acid-catalyzed reaction steps in a single catalytic cycle [85]. Based on the results presented in Fig. 8, it can be seen that at 350 °C, the selectivities of the products for the Ni-ZY catalyst are 7% (methane), 4% (ethane), 27% (propane), 5% (n-butane), 38% (iso-butane), and 19% (n-hexane), while for the CNT/Ni-ZY, these are 8% (methane), 2% (ethane), 45% (propane), 10% (n-butane), 27% (iso-butane), and 6% (n-hexane). Thus, it can be argued that there is likely secondary cracking that proceeds simultaneously, as primary cracking would produce alkanes with symmetric carbon distributions (i.e., equal amounts of C1 and C6, or C2 and C5, with C3 and C4 being the major products). It can also be observed that both catalysts favored hydrogenolysis reaction as expected from Ni-based catalysts. The iso-butane/propane ratios are 1.4 for Ni-ZY and 0.6–0.7 for CNT/Ni-ZY. This ratio is expected to be close to unity for n-heptane hydrogenolysis. Since the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst facilitates the methane production, while reducing the ethane formation, it can be expected that ethane to methane hydrogenolysis was also improved (C2H6+ H2 → 2 CH4) [86]. The differences in acidity of the two catalysts reported earlier (see Section 3.4) can be the reason for favored hydrogenolysis in the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst. Carbenium ions, formed after alkene protonation, may undergo a hydrogen transfer reaction into stable end-products, such as butanes, ethane and isohexane; alternatively, they can react with olefins to create larger molecules [87]. The olefin can also undergo a hydrogenation reaction over a metal particle. Ethylene, for instance, could migrate to a Ni particle and form a paraffin, here ethane (C2H6), through hydrogenation. In this study, CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst showed higher ethylene production than Ni-ZY, with the opposite trend for ethane selectivity. Therefore, it can be concluded that for this reaction pathway, dehydrogenation rather than hydrogenation was favored for the CNT-containing catalyst. Stability tests performed at 400 °C are presented in Fig. 8d and e for the Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts, respectively. After 20 h time-on-stream, the conversion slightly dropped by 14%-units for the Ni-ZY, and 10%-units for the CNT/Ni-ZY, whereas the product selectivity (%) changed only slightly. The drop in conversion is largely attributed to the accumulation of carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface, thus reducing the concentration of active sites, either through possible carburization of Ni, or plugging of porosity. Further coking studies were conducted and discussed in the following Section 3.8 aiming to interpret these catalytic activity/selectivity performance results, since the drop in the activity with TOS cannot be directly attributed to structural changes in the catalyst. 3.8 Coking studies - transient kinetic experiments The carbon accumulated after hydrocracking reaction (25% C7H16/75% H2) at 400 °C for 1, 2 and 3 h TOS was characterized by transient isothermal oxidation (TIO) experiments. The transient rates (μmol gcat -1 s-1) of CO and CO2 formation obtained during TIO on reduced NiO-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalysts are depicted in Fig. 9a–d, respectively. In all cases, the rates of CO and CO2 formation reach their maximum value within the first 15 s after the switch to the O2/He gas mixture in the reactor, followed by rapid decrease and an exponential-like decay extending to longer than 30 min in the case of CO2 formation (Fig. 9b, d) and to shorter times in the case of CO formation (Fig. 9a, c). In the case of CNT/Ni-ZY (Fig. 9c), there is a clear decrease in the initial transient rate of CO formation with TOS (ca. 1–3 h), as opposed to the case of NiO-ZY (Fig. 9a), but a similar decrease in the amount of carbon accumulated with TOS and oxidized to CO. In the case of transient kinetic rates of CO2 formation over the two catalytic surfaces, similar rates appear for the CNT/Ni-ZY for different TOS, as opposed to the case of NiO-ZY, where an increase of TOS from 1 h to 2 h is noted. This CO2 transient rate profile remains practically the same for a longer time on stream (ca. 3 h, Fig. 9d). It is noted that the observed transient kinetic rates are associated with the kinetics of carbon deposition on the metal surface, and thus depend on the structure of the carbon formed [88]. The total amount of carbon oxidized to CO and CO2 was quantified at 400 oC for various times on reaction stream, and this is reported for both catalysts in Table 4. The results show that the total amount of carbon formed was larger for the reduced NiO-ZY compared to CNT/Ni-ZY, justifying the enhanced activity and stability of the latter catalyst, as reported earlier in Section 3.7. The decomposition temperature of the NixCy phase is between 230 and 400 °C (and ∼ 465 °C for the metastable Ni3C), depending on its chemical composition [89,90]. This instability at elevated temperatures is due to the fcc-structured Ni in the NixCy phase, in which the voids between close packed atoms are insufficient to host carbon atoms (unlike bcc-structured metals) [91]. Yet, the CC bonds forming the CNT structure are stable at the studied reaction temperatures, which ensures the thermal stability of the catalyst. It is well known that metal sintering and carbon deposition both largely contribute to catalyst deactivation. Given that the temperature at the onset of Ni sintering ranges between 500 and 725 °C [92], and sintering of cemented carbides is insignificant below 800 °C [93], coking appears to be the most critical factor that determines the rate of catalyst deactivation in the present work. It has been reported that the size of Ni particles directly affects carbon formation during the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction, and a minimum Ni particle size (∼ 7 nm) is required for the growth of filamentous carbon [94]. The mean Ni particle in the Ni-ZY catalyst is smaller (ca. 24 nm) than that in CNT/Ni-ZY (ca. 33 nm) (Table 3). However, other factors might have also played a role in the reduction of coke formation over the CNT/Ni-ZY catalytic system. Coking can occur in the form of whisker-like carbon, where carbon atoms first diffuse through Ni crystals, nucleate and then whiskers grow with Ni crystal at the top, causing minimal deactivation of Ni [95]. One of the ways to minimize deactivation by coking is to facilitate the diffusion of coke away from the surface to the bulk of the catalyst, keeping the Ni active despite the accumulation of coke. It was shown that including a carbide-forming species in the catalyst would provide a sink for carbon deposited on the surface [96]. In the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst, the formation of nickel carbide phase, as proved from the XPS analysis (see Section 3.3), facilitates the diffusion of carbon away from the Ni surface, and this explains the catalyst’s reduced coke-forming tendency. Also, the effects of Ni versus NiO on coke deposition are quite different. In a comparison between Ni and NiO-based catalysts of the same support composition and gas pretreatments, Ni-based catalysts showed slightly lower coking after hydrocracking [97]. Although both catalysts in this study (Ni-ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY) were reduced prior to the reaction, there might exist a portion of NiO due to incomplete reduction in H2. The reduced carbon formation in the case of CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst preserves higher rates of dehydrogenation reactions on the surface of Ni particles, which in turn lead to higher catalytic activity, lower deactivation rates, and thus increased stability with time-on-stream. Although it can be argued that higher rates of dehydrogenation lead to an increased amount of coking precursors formation, the slow release of Ni particles out of the NixC due to their decomposition assists on the prolonged stability. After 3 h exposure of the catalysts to the hydrocracking reaction mixture (25 vol% C7H16 /75 vol% H2) at 400 oC, the amount of carbon accumulated was ∼ 20% lower for CNT/Ni-ZY compared to the reduced NiO-ZY catalyst. 3.9 Transient kinetics of n-C7H16/H2 reaction Transient kinetic experiments of the step-gas concentration switch mode [98] were conducted, namely, He → 25%C7H16/75%H2 (t) at 400 °C, to study the evolution rates of CH4 and C2H6 during hydrocracking of heptane. Time evolution of the transient rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation were recorded during 1, 2 and 3 h after the reaction feed gas stream was introduced in the reactor. After a given TOS (ca. 1 h), the reactor was purged in He gas flow, and then a step-gas concentration switch to a 2 vol%O2/He gas mixture at 400 °C (TIO, Fig. 9) was made to measure the carbon accumulated during the given reaction time (ca. 1 h), followed by He purge and H2 reduction steps, as described in detail in Section 2.2.9. Figs. 10a–c and 11a–c describe the transient evolution of the CH4 and C2H6 formation rates, respectively, over NiO/ZY and CNT/Ni-ZY catalytic surfaces. The transient formation rates of both gas products show an initial increase with a maximum rate value obtained within the first few minutes of reaction, ca. 3–6 min, where subsequently the rate drops to lower values. The latter can be explained as the result of carbon deposition on the surface of Ni nanoparticles [99]. This drop depends on the kinetics of carbon deposition on the specific metal surfaces, and on the structure of the carbon formed [100]. It is important to note that although the CH4 and C2H6 formation rates drop due to coking, they reach nearly plateau values after ∼ 60 min of reaction time, which is extended out to 3 h (no studies were made beyond this TOS). This indicates that deposition of carbonaceous species does not deactivate all active surface reaction sites, depending on the chemical composition of the former [89,90], or new active sites might had been formed at 400 °C, following NixC decomposition at 400 °C. The results presented in Fig. 10a–c show significantly higher CH4 initial and pseudo-steady state reaction rates for CNT/Ni-ZY compared to NiO-ZY, which can be attributed to the lower coke formation rates of the former during the hydrocracking reaction, as presented and discussed in Section 3.8. Furthermore, the CH4 formation rates of the CNT/Ni-ZY show either a double peak profile or a wide shoulder following the initial peak, which is not observed in the case of NiO/ZY catalyst. This may indicate that for CNT/Ni-ZY, the Ni particles embedded in the NixC were converted into fcc-Ni and C due to the high H2 concentration in the feed, thus releasing new Ni sites available for reaction which naturally cause the rate to increase again. It can be noticed that the transient rate profiles of CH4 and C2H6 recorded for the fresh catalysts during the first one hour of exposure to the reaction gas mixture are quite different compared to those recorded for 3 h TOS, following TIO between successive reaction runs (compare Figs. 10a and c and 11a and c). This phenomenon is likely to be the result of some modification of the surface structure of Ni or the support due to the exposure of the catalyst to 2%O2/He between the consecutive reaction runs. The pseudo-steady state rates achieved after ∼ 1 h TOS (Figs. 10c and 11c) are significantly higher for CH4 than C2H6 formation (∼ 10 times) for both catalysts. These results cannot be strictly compared to those shown in Fig. 8, primarily of the different partial pressures used in the two studies (5 bar vs 1 bar total pressure, same feed composition but different GHSV). In general, it appears that in both studies the CH4-selectivity is larger than that of C2H6. From a mechanistic perspective, the lower rate of carbon formation over the CNT/Ni-ZY suggests that higher concentration of Ni metal sites and surface acid sites of support are available for (de)hydrogenation and cracking, respectively (see Eqs. (1S)–(7S)), which contribute to higher rates of CH4 and C2H6 production compared to the NiO/ZY catalyst. Other intrinsic reasons that can explain the boosting of the ultimate catalytic activity of CNT/Ni-ZY include: (a) the high porosity that can accommodate more coke, thus CNTs serve as coke reservoirs, (b) the higher BET surface area and meso-porosity (see Section 3.1) reported for CNT/Ni-ZY, the latter contributing to the enhanced diffusion rates of reactants and products, and (c) the higher surface concentration of acid sites per gram basis, which is detrimental for enhanced hydrocracking activity. 3.10 Mechanistic aspects of heptane hydrocracking Understanding the surface catalytic chemistry during heptane hydrocracking is critical in an attempt to better explain the catalytic and kinetic results obtained in the present work. For this sake, important steps of the mechanism of heptane hydrocracking are described by Eqs. (S1)–(S7) in the Supplementary Material, and shown also in Fig. 12 according to experimental evidence [87]. Briefly, heptane molecules are first weakly chemisorbed on the support’s catalyst surface, where they subsequently migrate via diffusion to the Ni particles (metal active sites) on which chemisorption followed by the first dehydrogenation reaction step to produce heptene take place. Heptene then migrates to a Brønsted acid site originating from the zeolite Y support, where it undergoes protonation to form a carbenium ion. A series of elementary reaction steps then take place producing the wide range of product molecules identified in the present work. For instance, the carbenium ions get isomerized via alkyl shifts or protonated cyclopropane (PCP) steps, which are then cracked into smaller molecules through β-scission to form olefins and shorter carbenium ions [87]. Olefins can be further cracked on the acid sites or hydrogenated over Ni metal sites [87], whereas carbenium ions can be deprotonated to form olefins, which then produce paraffins through hydrogenation steps [87]. In the present study, the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst by reducing the coke formation maintains higher dehydrogenation rates for the heptane molecules on Ni active sites, thus leading to an increased catalytic activity. Additionally, the presence of NixC phase ensured the slow release of Ni particles upon its decomposition and in the presence of H2 gas stream, facilitating prolonged stability of the catalyst (see Section 3.7). 4 Conclusions In this study, hydrocracking of heptane was performed at 350 and 400 °C using a bi-functional CNT/Ni-ZY composite catalyst. The heptane conversion (84%, 400 oC) and propane selectivity (44%, 400 °C) as well as the bulk and surface properties of the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst were compared to those of a conventional Ni-ZY catalyst with same Ni-loading to enlighten the role of CNTs in the reaction metrics and coking resistance. Transient isothermal kinetic rates and isothermal oxygen titration of carbonaceous species accumulated with TOS, as well as in-situ acidity measurements (use of ammonia) of the working catalyst surface (after reaction for given TOS) proved to be very useful tools in revealing fundamental information about catalyst’s activity and resistance against deactivation. The incorporation of CNTs in the Ni-ZY catalyst improved the conversion of heptane from 62% to 76% at 350 °C, and from 78% to 84% at 400 °C, equivalent to an increase of 22% and 7% at 350 °C and 400 °C, respectively. CNT/Ni-ZY showed a remarkable increase in the selectivity towards lighter products (e.g., propane) compared to Ni-ZY, where an increase by 70–75% in propane selectivity was noticed. Also, the increased stability for 20 h TOS was demonstrated in the case of CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst with only ∼ 10% loss of activity. Titration with oxygen in a dynamic mode (transient isothermal oxidation) of the accumulated carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface after 3 h of reaction confirmed a reduced amount (∼ 20%) of carbonaceous deposits on the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst compared to Ni-ZY, which can be attributed to the role of CNTs as coke reservoir, mainly due to the mesoporosity induced by CNTs, and the presence of smaller Ni particles in the catalyst because of CNTs growth. CNTs also contribute to the enhancement of catalyst performance by being catalytically active components of the catalyst. For example, Si/SiO2 from zeolites can diffuse over the CNT walls and act as cracking sites. Transient kinetic rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation suggest that these gaseous products are formed faster and in larger amounts over the CNT/Ni-ZY catalyst compared to NiO-ZY, suggesting that the latter is a promising hydrocracking catalyst, as it is potent towards lighter products and is more resistant to coking. The findings of this study suggest that the integration of CNTs into Ni-based hydrocracking catalysts offers new opportunities for enhancing their catalytic activity and selectivity to light olefins and their coking resistance. It is worth mentioning that hydrocracking of a model compound, such as heptane, can be extended to larger molecules using catalyst design concepts presented in this study. Thus, further work is needed to study the performance of these novel catalysts in the hydrocracking of other fossil or renewable feedstock, which could reveal the full potential of such a catalyst design approach. coredata.dc:description: The effect of integrating carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into a bi-functional Ni-Zeolite-Y catalyst was studied for the hydrocracking of heptane at 350 and 400 °C (total pressure of 5 bar). It was shown that the growth of CNTs on the surface of Ni-Zeolite-Y (Ni-ZY) results in enhanced stability and catalytic activity (conversion increased by 22% at 350 °C) compared to the conventional Ni-ZY. A significant increase in the initial transient kinetic rates of CH4 and C2H6 formation was also noticed. The CNT/Ni-ZY also showed reduced coke formation during the reaction as entailed by transient isothermal (400 °C) oxidation experiments. The formation of a crystalline NixCy phase on the zeolite surface was observed in the case of CNT/Ni-ZY, potentially responsible for its enhanced catalytic performance. This work demonstrates that the integration of CNTs in hydrocracking catalysts offers new opportunities for enhancing their catalytic activity, selectivity and coking resistance.
coredata.dc:title: Ni/CNT/Zeolite-Y composite catalyst for efficient heptane hydrocracking: Steady-state and transient kinetic studies
